read.title: The Tyrant’s Tomb (The Trials of Apollo, #4)
read.author: Rick Riordan

read.title: Stay True
read.author: Hua Hsu
read.my_review: Moving and reflective: a beautiful exploration of identity, assimilation, friendship, and loss.

read.title: Ace: What Asexuality Reveals About Desire, Society, and the Meaning of Sex
read.author: Angela  Chen
read.my_review: A great book for someone who is coming to terms with their asexuality identity and wants to learn more or someone progressive who wants to understand how contemporary ideas of sex and romance cause harm to people/society.

read.title: Polysecure: Attachment, Trauma and Consensual Nonmonogamy
read.author: Jessica Fern
read.my_review:
More about attachment than anything else which makes this book very broadly applicable, even to people who are 100% only interested in monogamy.

This book definitely opened my mind to various things that I will take with me and continue to reflect on.

read.title: I Who Have Never Known Men
read.author: Jacqueline Harpman
read.my_review:
This book is equally haunting and thought provoking. It has so much to say about living and what it means to be human.

I don’t think this book will appeal to everyone because of the sheer number of unanswered questions, but that’s kind of the point, so if you can deal with that, then I think you’ll get a lot out of this book.

read.title: Rebirth of the Thief Who Roamed The World (Rebirth of the Thief Who Roamed The World, #3)
read.author: Mad Snail

read.title: Rebirth of the Thief Who Roamed The World (Rebirth of the Thief Who Roamed The World, #2)
read.author: Mad Snail

read.title: Rebirth of the Thief Who Roamed The World (Rebirth of the Thief Who Roamed The World, #1)
read.author: Mad Snail

read.title: How to Do Nothing: Resisting the Attention Economy
read.author: Jenny Odell
read.my_review: A wonderful meandering book with a strong central thesis that is somewhat misrepresented by the title (imo). It is about paying attention to your place, both space and time, in order to live a fuller life and resist the pace and destruction of modern times

read.title: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes (The Hunger Games, #0)
read.author: Suzanne Collins

read.title: The Art of Gathering: How We Meet and Why It Matters
read.author: Priya Parker
read.my_review: A book that serves more as a philosophical reminder that gatherings are important and can be transformative rather than giving you hard and fast rules on hosting. However for me that works because it gave me ideas and license to be a more involved host.

read.title: The Other Significant Others: Reimagining Life with Friendship at the Center
read.author: Rhaina Cohen
read.my_review: A fascinating book that shows the possibilities of building your life beyond the default of a monogamous romantic marriage and nuclear family. This book focuses more on showing possibility rather than making normative claims for you to do one thing or the other. I think that anyone who is not convinced that social defaults are one-size-fits-all to read this book to get inspired.

read.title: The Burning Maze (The Trials of Apollo, #3)
read.author: Rick Riordan

read.title: The Meaning of Travel: Philosophers Abroad
read.author: Emily Thomas
read.my_review: A very fun and interesting look at the various philosophical aspects of travel

read.title: What Love Is: And What It Could Be
read.author: Carrie Jenkins
read.my_review: A great survey of the current philosophical and scientific work on what love is socially and biologically. She presents good arguments on why we should change our conception of romantic love and what that might look like. I think she sometimes does not engage with opposing claims too much, but I think that’s alright and just leaves the opening for other work in response to hers.

read.title: Four Thousand Weeks: Time Management for Mortals
read.author: Oliver Burkeman
read.my_review: This book made me reflect a lot but I felt like it was not going as deep into exploring points as much as I wanted it to. It also felt repetitive at times, but I think that this book is a great overview of topics for yourself to pick from to take and work on in your life.

read.title: On Bullshit
read.author: Harry G. Frankfurt
read.my_review:
I’m not quite sure where to start with this review because it is a bit of a strange case. This is originally an essay (~20 pages) and then was bound in the smallest possible book to squeeze it out to almost 70 pages. I’m not sure if it’s a commitment to the bit or what because this topic of inquiry could be seen as humorous from the outside but is treated with no humor by the author. Instead this is a very straightforward inquiry into the nature of bullshit. I tend to agree mostly with the author’s claims, but I’m not sure why the scope of his inquiry is so narrow. In some ways he seems to refuse to engage with the pragmatics of communication and bullshit, either as a philosophical commitment or because he wanted to be focused in his scope.

Either way, this is an interesting essay to read, so if you are interested in bullshit or analytic philosophy I would say to give it a read, but you could just look up the essay online instead of buying the book.

read.title: Being Mortal: Medicine and What Matters in the End
read.author: Atul Gawande
read.my_review: Only had one anxiety attack about contemplating the reality of my own mortality! However, more than that this book gave me a lot of hope. Hope in humanity’s quest in improving our transition into death, that we might be able to reduce suffering and increase overall well-being.

read.title: The Dark Prophecy (The Trials of Apollo, #2)
read.author: Rick Riordan

read.title: Assholes: A Theory
read.author: Aaron James
read.my_review:
If I could give this book 4.5 stars, I would. I have some mixed feelings about this book and its intended purposes and audience, but on the whole I really enjoyed reading this book. It is on its face about the philosophy of assholes, but I think a lot of the book hinges on capitalist critique (which I am always in the mood for). I wouldn't recommend this book to everyone, but I think for those of whom it falls under their interests, they will definitely enjoy this read.

I have my extended thoughts about this book here: https://reesdraminski.com/notes/assholes-a-theory/

read.title: In Limbo
read.author: Deb J.J. Lee
read.my_review: I don’t feel comfortable rating this book because it didn’t resonate with me and at no fault of the author or the book. With that being said, the art style is beautiful in print and there are some really creative panels in this book.

read.title: When Breath Becomes Air
read.author: Paul Kalanithi
read.my_review:
Gorgeous, gripping, and absolutely crushing; I couldn’t put this book down and sobbed at its end.

I would sincerely recommend this book to anyone who wants to become a doctor and/or someone who thinks deeply about the meanings of both life and death.

read.title: Crying in H Mart
read.author: Michelle Zauner
read.my_review: pain!

read.title: I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki
read.author: Baek Se-hee
read.my_review:
I don’t find many of the anecdotes to be personally relatable but I think that’s understandable because it was very much a part of her journey and indicative of where she was as a result of how she was raised/grew up.

I do think that I was able to take lessons from what she was saying though. I think that this book overall is great for the normalization of mental health care like medication and therapy. Additionally, it offers us concrete examples of what happens with cognition distortions like black and white thinking and how it actually can affect our moods, relationships, and daily lives.

read.title: The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue
read.author: Victoria Schwab

read.title: This Is How You Lose the Time War
read.author: Amal El-Mohtar
read.my_review: could feel the yearning thru the pages—time stuff always makes me confused tho

owned.title: Stay True
owned.author: Hua Hsu
owned.my_review: Moving and reflective: a beautiful exploration of identity, assimilation, friendship, and loss.

owned.title: Ace: What Asexuality Reveals About Desire, Society, and the Meaning of Sex
owned.author: Angela  Chen
owned.my_review: A great book for someone who is coming to terms with their asexuality identity and wants to learn more or someone progressive who wants to understand how contemporary ideas of sex and romance cause harm to people/society.

owned.title: Polysecure: Attachment, Trauma and Consensual Nonmonogamy
owned.author: Jessica Fern
owned.my_review:
More about attachment than anything else which makes this book very broadly applicable, even to people who are 100% only interested in monogamy.

This book definitely opened my mind to various things that I will take with me and continue to reflect on.

owned.title: I Who Have Never Known Men
owned.author: Jacqueline Harpman
owned.my_review:
This book is equally haunting and thought provoking. It has so much to say about living and what it means to be human.

I don’t think this book will appeal to everyone because of the sheer number of unanswered questions, but that’s kind of the point, so if you can deal with that, then I think you’ll get a lot out of this book.

owned.title: The Song of Achilles
owned.author: Madeline Miller

owned.title: How to Do Nothing: Resisting the Attention Economy
owned.author: Jenny Odell
owned.my_review: A wonderful meandering book with a strong central thesis that is somewhat misrepresented by the title (imo). It is about paying attention to your place, both space and time, in order to live a fuller life and resist the pace and destruction of modern times

owned.title: The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up: The Japanese Art of Decluttering and Organizing
owned.author: Marie Kondō

owned.title: I'm Still Trying To Figure It All Out Myself...
owned.author: Larry   Cohen

owned.title: The Art of Gathering: How We Meet and Why It Matters
owned.author: Priya Parker
owned.my_review: A book that serves more as a philosophical reminder that gatherings are important and can be transformative rather than giving you hard and fast rules on hosting. However for me that works because it gave me ideas and license to be a more involved host.

owned.title: The Other Significant Others: Reimagining Life with Friendship at the Center
owned.author: Rhaina Cohen
owned.my_review: A fascinating book that shows the possibilities of building your life beyond the default of a monogamous romantic marriage and nuclear family. This book focuses more on showing possibility rather than making normative claims for you to do one thing or the other. I think that anyone who is not convinced that social defaults are one-size-fits-all to read this book to get inspired.

owned.my_review: A very fun and interesting look at the various philosophical aspects of travel

owned.title: A Natural History of the Romance Novel
owned.author: Pamela Regis

owned.title: What Love Is: And What It Could Be
owned.author: Carrie Jenkins
owned.my_review: A great survey of the current philosophical and scientific work on what love is socially and biologically. She presents good arguments on why we should change our conception of romantic love and what that might look like. I think she sometimes does not engage with opposing claims too much, but I think that’s alright and just leaves the opening for other work in response to hers.

owned.title: Four Thousand Weeks: Time Management for Mortals
owned.author: Oliver Burkeman
owned.my_review: This book made me reflect a lot but I felt like it was not going as deep into exploring points as much as I wanted it to. It also felt repetitive at times, but I think that this book is a great overview of topics for yourself to pick from to take and work on in your life.

owned.title: Immortality: The Quest to Live Forever and How It Drives Civilization
owned.author: Stephen  Cave

owned.title: On Bullshit
owned.author: Harry G. Frankfurt
owned.my_review:
I’m not quite sure where to start with this review because it is a bit of a strange case. This is originally an essay (~20 pages) and then was bound in the smallest possible book to squeeze it out to almost 70 pages. I’m not sure if it’s a commitment to the bit or what because this topic of inquiry could be seen as humorous from the outside but is treated with no humor by the author. Instead this is a very straightforward inquiry into the nature of bullshit. I tend to agree mostly with the author’s claims, but I’m not sure why the scope of his inquiry is so narrow. In some ways he seems to refuse to engage with the pragmatics of communication and bullshit, either as a philosophical commitment or because he wanted to be focused in his scope.

Either way, this is an interesting essay to read, so if you are interested in bullshit or analytic philosophy I would say to give it a read, but you could just look up the essay online instead of buying the book.

owned.title: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow
owned.author: Gabrielle Zevin

owned.title: Being Mortal: Medicine and What Matters in the End
owned.author: Atul Gawande
owned.my_review: Only had one anxiety attack about contemplating the reality of my own mortality! However, more than that this book gave me a lot of hope. Hope in humanity’s quest in improving our transition into death, that we might be able to reduce suffering and increase overall well-being.

owned.title: Assholes: A Theory
owned.author: Aaron James
owned.my_review:
If I could give this book 4.5 stars, I would. I have some mixed feelings about this book and its intended purposes and audience, but on the whole I really enjoyed reading this book. It is on its face about the philosophy of assholes, but I think a lot of the book hinges on capitalist critique (which I am always in the mood for). I wouldn't recommend this book to everyone, but I think for those of whom it falls under their interests, they will definitely enjoy this read.

I have my extended thoughts about this book here: https://reesdraminski.com/notes/assholes-a-theory/

owned.title: When Breath Becomes Air
owned.author: Paul Kalanithi
owned.my_review:
Gorgeous, gripping, and absolutely crushing; I couldn’t put this book down and sobbed at its end.

I would sincerely recommend this book to anyone who wants to become a doctor and/or someone who thinks deeply about the meanings of both life and death.

owned.title: I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki
owned.author: Baek Se-hee
owned.my_review:
I don’t find many of the anecdotes to be personally relatable but I think that’s understandable because it was very much a part of her journey and indicative of where she was as a result of how she was raised/grew up.

I do think that I was able to take lessons from what she was saying though. I think that this book overall is great for the normalization of mental health care like medication and therapy. Additionally, it offers us concrete examples of what happens with cognition distortions like black and white thinking and how it actually can affect our moods, relationships, and daily lives.
